loans.name: Rodolfo

texts.es:
Rodolfo is divorced and has two children, aged 12 and 16. Due to the lack of employment that exists in the country, he decided to start his own business offering his services as a taxi driver. He wants to give his children a good education and help them to what career end that they might have the best opportunities in teh future. This is the strongest motivation that he has to go to work and to strive for more every day.

To be able to offer better service to his customers Rodolfo now needs a credit of $475 that he will use in the repair and maintenance of his taxi, with the objective of preventing whatever sort of accident that could occur. He commits himself to repay this loan in six months. Become an important part in the life of this family and deciD. to aid Rodolfo; he is very grateful for the opportunity to improve that you offer.

Translated from Spanish by Pax Bobrow, Kiva Volunteer.

Rodolfo es divorciado y tiene dos hijos, D. 12 y 16 años D. edad, ente la falta D. empleo que hay en el país decidió iniciar su propio negocio ofreciendo sus servicios D. taxista, él quiere darle a sus hijos una buena educación y ayudarlos a que terminen su carrera para que tengan mejores oportunidades en el futuro, este es el motivo más fuerte que tiene para salir a trabajar y esforzarse más cada día.

Para poder ofrecer un mejor servicio a sus clientes ahora Rodolfo necesita D. un crédito D. $ 475 dólares que utilizará en la reparación y mantenimiento D. su taxi, con el objetivo D. evitar cualquier tipo D. accidente que pudiera ocurrir, él se compromete a regresar este préstamo en 6 meses. Se parte importante en la vida D. esta familia y decídete a apoyar a Rodolfo, él agradece mucho la oportunidad que le brindas D. mejorar.

loans.use:
Repair and maintenance of his taxi - 
Reparación y mantenimiento

location.town: San Nicolás de los Garza, Nuevo León

loans.name: Claudia Selene

texts.es:
Claudia is an enterprising young woman with great wishes of self-improvement. She is single and to be able to cover the costs of her studies, she decided to start her own business offering her services as a beauty stylist a year and a half ago. Her taste for this trade has helped her to realize work of very good quality. Now she also applies acrylic nails and eyelash extensions. Little by little she has made herself known and has increased the number of her customers.

Claudia wishes to be able to continue growing her business and requests a credit of $475 that she will use in the purchase of supplies to be able to cover the demand for her services. She commits herself to repay this amount in just three months. Be part of Claudia's successes; she is very grateful for the opportunity that you offer for improvement and belief in her business.

Translated from Spanish by Pax Bobrow, Kiva Volunteer.

Claudia es una joven emprendedora con grandes deseos de superación, es soltera y para poder cubrir los costos de sus estudios decidió iniciar su propio negocio ofreciendo sus servicios de estilista hace un año y medio, su gusto por este oficio le ha ayudado a realizar trabajos de muy buena calidad, ahora también aplica uñas acrílicas y extensiones de pestañas, poco a poco se ha dado a conocer y ha incrementado su número de clientes.

Claudia desea poder continuar creciendo con su negocio y solicita de un crédito de $ 475 dólares que utilizará en la compra de insumos para poder cubrir la demanda por sus servicios, ella se compromete a regresar esta cantidad en solo tres meses. Se parte en los logros de Claudia, ella agradece mucho la oportunidad que le brindas de mejorara y hacer creer su negocio.

loans.use:
Purchase of supplies for beauty salon - 

Compra de insumos

loans.name: Janet

texts.es:
The C. family is dedicated to the sale of tacos. The entrepreneur's sons attend to the business and her husband is in charge of cooking and making sure everything is well prepared. The family is asking for a loan of $1,200 dollars to buy a refrigerator and a new motor for the van where they sell their delicious tacos every morning.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Kirkvold, Kiva volunteer.

La familia C. se dedica a la venta de tacos. Los que atiende el negocio son sus hijos ella y su esposo es encargan de hacer los guisados en la casa y así estar mas preparados. Estamos solicitando un préstamo de $1,200.00 Dlls. Para comprar un refrigerador y un motor nuevo a la camioneta que es donde vendemos nuestros deliciosos tacos todas las mañanas.

loans.use: refrigerator and motor for the van

loans.name: Migdalia

texts.es:
Migdalia is married and has two small children. Her husband has a carpentry workshop but on occasion there would be no work and it was very difficult to cover the costs of the home. Before this necessity, Migdalia started her own business in the sale and application of facial treatments a year ago. The products that she sells are well received by her clientele and fortunately her sales are growing very rapidly.

Migdalia now needs a credit for $250 that will be destined for the purchase of merchandise to be able to cover the demands of her clientele. She commits herself to repay this amount in only three months. Be an important part in the development of this business. Migdalia and her family need and are very grateful for the support that you can offer them.

Translated from Spanish by Pax Bobrow, Kiva Volunteer.

Migdalia es casada y tiene dos pequeños hijos, su esposo tiene un taller de carpintería pero en ocasiones no tenía trabajo y era muy difícil cubrir todos los gastos del hogar, ante esta necesidad Migdalia inició su propio negocio con la venta y aplicación de tratamientos faciales hace un año, los productos que comercializa tienen mucha aceptación entre sus clientes y afortunadamente sus ventas crecieron muy rápido.

Migdalia necesita ahora de un crédito por $ 250 dólares que destinará a la compra de mercancía para poder cubrir la demanda de sus clientes, ella se compromete a devolver esta cantidad en sólo 3 meses. Se parte importante en el desarrollo de este negocio, MIgdalia y su familia necesitan y agradecen mucho el apoyo que puedas brindarles.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise for facials - Compra de mercancía

loans.name: Alejandrina

texts.es:
Alejandrina comes from the locality of Linares in the state of Nuevo Leon. She is a widow with three children. They were the motivation for her when she started eight years ago with the sale of cosmetics. Her children were studying outside the locality and without a husband, she had to continue covering those costs. Fortunately the good quality of the products that she sells and her taste for sales has permitted her business to grow.

To be able to cover the orders of her clients, Alejandrina is requesting a credit for $250 that she will employ in the purchase of merchandise. She offers to repay this amount in three months. In your hands is the well-being of this family, contributing to the growth of this business; think no more and decide to support them.

Translated from Spanish by Pax Bobrow, Kiva Volunteer.

Alejandrina es originaria de la localidad de Linares en el estado de Nuevo León, es viuda y tiene tres hijos, ellos fueron el motivo por el cual hace ocho años inició con la venta de cosméticos, sus hijos estaban estudiando fuera de la localidad y al faltar su esposo ella tenía que seguir cubriendo estos costos, afortunadamente la buena calidad de los productos que comercializa y su gusto por las ventas le ha permitido hacer crecer su negocio.

Para poder cubrir los pedidos de sus clientes Alejandrina está solicitando un crédito por $ 250 dólares que empleará en la compra de mercancía, ella ofrece regresar esta cantidad en tres meses. En tus manos está el bienestar de esta familia, contribuyendo al crecimiento de este negocio, no lo pienses más y decídete a apoyarlos.

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetics merchandise - Compra de mercancía

loans.name: Gloria Margarita

texts.es:
Gloria is single and has one daughter. She has never counted on the support of her partner for the support of her daughter, because of this she has had to work a lot and began her own business with the sale of snack food five years ago. She started selling snacks to foreign students who rented close to her home; later she became well known and they would demand more each time. This is how later she was able to condition a site to better attend to her customers.

Gloria is requesting a loan of $250 that she will use on the purchase of ingredients for the creation of her snacks, with which she hopes to increase the variety of dishes and better the quality of service she offers. She is prepared to repay this amount in three months. Become part of Gloria's success and contribute to the growth of her business; she is sincerely grateful to you.

Translated from Spanish by Pax Bobrow, Kiva Volunteer.

Gloria es soltera y tiene una hija. Nunca ha contado con el apoyo de su pareja para el sustento de su hija, por lo que ha tenido que trabajar mucho e inició su propio negocio con la venta de comidas hace cinco años, inició vendiendo comidas a los estudiantes foráneos que rentaban cerca de su hogar, después se dio a conocer y le demandaban más cada vez, así es como después logró acondicionar un local para atender mejor a sus clientes.

Gloria está solicitando un préstamo de $ 250 dólares que empleará en la compra de insumos para la elaboración de sus comidas, con lo que espera incrementar la variedad de platillos y mejorar la calidad del servicio que ofrece, ella esta dispuesta a regresar esta cantidad en 3 meses. Forma parte de los logros de Gloria y contribuye al crecimiento de su negocio, ella te lo agradece sinceramente.

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients for her snack stand  - Compra de insumos

loans.name: Faasegi

texts.en: There are thirteen members of Faasegi’s family. Three of her children are attending school. Her business is mainly in bakery products. She bakes German Buns and donuts, which support her family mainly by selling them in school compounds. It is the best place to sell her goods because there are no competitors like her, which gives her the best opportunity to get a higher income. Her sale for one day is about $90 tala profit and  $300 per week. She intends to save a bit of her profit in her savings account for emergency after all her expenses have been deducted.

loans.use: Faasegi would like to buy bags of flour, sacks of sugar, oil, yeast and a frying pan for her bun & donut shop.

loans.name: Hoji

texts.en:
B. Hoji is 49 years old, and she has a secondary-level education. She is married but her husband does not work.

B. Hoji previously worked as a cleaner in a hospital. She decided to start a business because the salary was not enough. She sells sport bags in the Panjshanbe bazaar. She has been in this business 6 years. She brings bags from Bishkek and Istaravshan. Her daughter helps to sell bags. B. wants to purchase a new model of bags from Bishkek and wants to introduce sport clothing. This loan will help her to obtain goods at moderate prices.

loans.use: To purchase a new model of bags and sport clothing.

loans.name: Fialii

texts.en: Fialii F. is one of the older ladies within the Vaipuna Center. She is on her first loan, which she will use in her bingo business. She is sixty years of age and this is the type of business she can manage to do. Saturday and Friday are the days that she played her bingo because this is the day in which people get their money. Fialii earned  $300.00 tala per night and she wants to expand her business, by buying more goods and attracting more people to play her bingo.

loans.use: Fialii would like to buy boxes of noodles and prizes for her Bingo business.

loans.name: Mayram

texts.ru:
Mayram A. is manufacturing and selling "massi" (national leather boots). Mayram is married and has three children. Her youngest daughter is in school, her son is working, and her middle daughter is married. Mayram has a post-secondary education and works as a nurse in a polyclinic. Mayram’s husband is a construction worker; he also helps Mayram with her business. Previously Mayram was ordering materials for producing boots from a distributor. After receiving a previous loan her husband began traveling to purchase materials himself. Mayram learned how to make “massi” from her husband. In the future, Mayram wants to open a shop to produce national boots “massi” with natural furskin and galoshes.

Translated from Russian by Keith & Jamilya Leitich, Kiva Volunteers.

Акбарова Майрам занимается производством и продажей масси (это национальнные кожаные сапоги ). Замужем, имеет троих детей. Младшая дочь учится в школе. Старший сын работает. Средняя дочь замужем. Муж работает строителем, также помогает жене в её деятельности. Образование среднее специальное. Раньше заказывала материалы для производства поставщикам. После получения займа стал ездить за материалами её муж. Этим ремеслом она научилась у своего мужа. Она также работает медсестрой в поликлинике. В дальнейшем хочет открыть цех, производить национальные масси с натуральным мехом и галоши

loans.use: increasing goods

loans.name: Khayrinisso

texts.en:
Khayrinisso A. is 34 years old and she has a secondary education. She is married and has 3 children. When Khayrinisso graduated from school, her parents did not allow her to continue her education. She got married and was a housewife and looked after her children. The civil war touched the Khayrinisso family and she was forced to look for a job, but was unsuccessful.

After that, Khayrinisso decided to start a business. She started to sell kids' clothes. When she got a good profit from the business, she started to change the range of goods. Currently she sells kerchiefs and women's underwear as well. It has been10 years since she started selling. To sell her goods quickly, Khayrinisso sells them for lower prices than others, so her goods do not stay long.

For the loan amount of $875, Khayrinisso is going to buy a new range of kids' clothes and women's underwear. This loan helps to increase the range of kids' goods and gives the inhabitants the opportunity to obtain goods for low prices. Khayrinisso is going to pay off the loan in 8 months.

loans.use: To increase turnover by selling a new range of kids' clothes

loans.name: Shakir

texts.en:
Shakir is an IDP from Fizuli, an occupied district of Azerbaijan. Shakir is a caring husband and also a father of four children. In 1993, he fled Fizuli to make Baku his new home. In 1996, he launched his idea to start an auto repair business. In 2005, Shakir received his first loan from Normicro Baku. This provided the initial funding to help him build his first small auto services shop.

Just this year, Shakir received a second loan from the same organization and completed building of his shop. Currently, he hopes to borrow a total amount of $1,100 so that he can renovate his current inventory of auto equipment.

loans.use: To purchase materials to renovate auto equipment

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi H. has been working very hard to raise her two children for 7 years. Her husband left the family to go down south, making her life (which is already hard) become even harder. H.’s main job is to make rice pancake. She wakes up to work from 3 a.m. everyday. She finishes making the rice pancake at 5.am., then spends her whole morning to deliver the pancakes to the restaurants. Because her pancakes are good, she often finishes selling everything before noon. Each pancake brings her a profit of $0.012. On average, Ms. H. earns $3.5 a day. This amount is mostly spent for the food and the school bills. Now Ms. H. is looking forward to borrow $125 to buy more rice and sesame – the ingredients for her rice pancakes- to increase the amount of pancakes sold everyday during the summer.

Translated from Vietnamese by PH. Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Hương một mình làm việc để nuôi 2 con ăn học từ 7 năm nay. Chồng chị bỏ vào miền Nam khiến hoàn cảnh gia đình đã khó khăn lại càng thêm khó khăn. Công việc chủ yếu của chị là làm bánh đa. Chị Hương dậy tráng bánh từ 3 giờ sáng. Việc tráng bánh được hoàn tất vào lúc 5 giờ, sau đó toàn bộ buổi sáng là thời gian chị Hương mang bánh đi giao cho các cửa hàng. Bánh chị làm có chất lượng cao nên toàn bộ số bánh thường được bán hết trước buổi trưa. Mỗi chiếc bánh làm ra chị lãi được 0,012 USD, trung bình một ngày chị Hương thu nhập khoảng 3,5 USD. Số tiền này chủ yếu được chi dùng cho việc mua thức ăn hàng ngày và trả học phí cho các con. Hiện tại chị Hương đang làm đơn xin vay 125 USD để mua thêm gạo, vừng để tăng số lượng bánh bán ra mỗi ngày trong mùa hè.

loans.use: buy rice and sesame to make rice pancake

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Since Ms. Nguyen Thi H.’s husband died in an accident, she becomes the only one who earns the living for the whole family. At the age of 52, H. works very hard to pay for her two children’s schooling. All her money comes from a small grocery store. Because of her cordiality, her store is often crowded. Ms. H. always hopes that her children would succeed. That is also the motivation for her to never stop trying both at work and in life. She is applying for a loan of $250, so that she can buy goods for her grocery store.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chồng mất trong một tai nạn, toàn bộ gánh nặng gia đình dồn lên hai vai chị Nguyễn Thị Huấn. Ở độ tuổi 52 chị Huấn vẫn làm việc tích cực để nuôi 2 con ăn học. Mọi khoản thu trong gia đình chị Huấn đều trông vào cửa hàng tạp hóa. Luôn vui vẻ niềm nở, phục vụ tận tình đối với mọi người nên cửa hàng của chị lúc nào cũng đông khách. Niềm hy vọng của chị Huấn là được thấy con cái học hành thành đạt, đó cũng chính là động lực thúc đẩy chị vững bước trong công việc cũng như trong cuộc sống. Chị đang làm đơn xin vay số tiền 250 USD để mua thêm một số mặt hàng cho cửa hàng tạp hóa của mình.

loans.use: buy goods for her grocery store

loans.name: Mavluda

texts.en:
Mavluda is a divorced, she has raised her son herself without help from others. Mavluda is one of the first clients of our organization She is thankful to MicroInvest because with her previous loans she was able to develop her business and with the income help to her son to study at secondary school. Next year her son will finish secondary school. Mavluda wants to help her son to enter university next year.

Mavluda is engaged in the retail trade of packaging, which she imports from China. Mavluda has been in this business for 13 years. She started the business with 50 dollars. Now her business place is very small. She has a lot of clients, and Mavluda wants to increase her assortment and to rent a new bigger shop. Beside packaging, she wants to sell foodstuffs.

loans.use: To increase volume of assets and try to buy goods at wholesale price.

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi:
For the past 5 years, the little restaurant of Mrs Vân is a familiar address for the local villagers of Lưu Sơn (Đô Lương district). Despite the fact that the restaurant is quite busy from morning until night, the patrons always receive good service from Mrs Vân. They appreciate the fact that she treats all her customers the same way, no matter what their social status is. Mrs Vân’s husband and her 2 daughters help her out after their classes, waiting on patrons. Her dream is to make her little restaurant a popular spot, a meeting place for the local villagers and also to attract customers from out of town. She’s requesting a loan of 250 USD to stock more food and drink for her restaurant.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer.

Từ 5 năm nay, cửa hàng ăn của chị Vân là địa chỉ quen thuộc người dân xã Lưu Sơn, huyện Đô Lương. Bận rộn từ sáng đến tối nhưng những khách hàng đến cửa hàng không bao giờ phải than phiền về việc phục vụ kém chất lượng hay thái độ của chủ hàng. Bà chủ quán ăn 47 tuổi này luôn chu đáo với mọi tầng lớp khách hàng. Chồng chị và hai con gái ngoài giờ học cũng tích cực phụ giúp chị trong việc phục vụ khách. Ước muốn của chị Vân là cửa hàng của chị sẽ ngày càng quen thuộc hơn với không chỉ người dân trong xã mà còn với những khách ở xa. Chị Vân đang đề nghị Quỹ cho vay mức vốn 250 USD để mua thêm đồ uống và thức ăn cho quán ăn.

loans.use: buy drink and food for her restaurant

loans.name: Маtluba

texts.en:
Matluba Asoeva is 21 years old. She has a secondary education. She is single. Matluba grew up in a poor family so she had no opportunity to continue her education and she learned how to sew national dresses and caps for women. She acquired sewing skills very fast and became a professional seamstress. Summer is wedding season, so she sews dresses and caps for brides and in winter she knits woolen clothes to provides warmth.

Her business brings a good income to her family. She has three years of experience in this business. For the loan amount for $1000, Matluba is going to buy materials for dresses and national caps. Also she is going to buy yarn to knit warm clothes, because in winter the yarn will be more expensive. This loan helps to increase the range of women's dresses and provides inexpensive materials for knitting warm clothes, thus providing good-quality cheap clothes. Matluba is going to pay off the loan for 12 months.

loans.use: To buy materials (fabric, yarn)

loans.name: Amil

texts.en:
Amil is an IDP originally from Fizuli, an occupied district of Azerbaijan. In 1993, he fled to Baku. Though he is currently single, he is waiting to earn a higher income so that he can save and spend it on a wedding.

Amil first started his business in 2000. However, he had no sufficient working capital to sustain the business. In 2005, he received his first loan from the Normicro Baku branch. This helped to increase his working capital for his business. In time, he received a second loan from the same organization. Now, he is applying for a $1,100 loan so that he can diversify the assortment of his goods.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs Trần Thị Bảy, 47 years old, live with her husband in Sóc Sơn, a district just outside of Hà Nội. She received her first micro loan more than 10 years ago. It was a very small amount: 25 USD. With that money, she started her business of buying scrap material then resell. Other people in the same business barely make enough money to survive. For them, there is no opportunity for expansion in this kind of business. For Mrs Bảy it's a different story. With her determination combined with a high degree of organization, she had made her buy/resell scrap material business into a very viable one. What started out as a small business 10 years ago, buying small quantity of wasted material to resell, is now a well organized and successful one. She now buys her wasted materials in big quantities. These are then categorized and resold to various factories. Mrs Bảy has 3 children, all grown up and they all work with her. She is requesting a loan of 1200 USD to buy more materials thus to further expand her business

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Trần Thị Bảy, 47 tuổi sống cùng chồng tại Sóc Sơn, một huyện ngoại thành Hà Nội. Chị đã tham gia vay vốn từ hơn 10 năm nay. Bắt đầu từ 25 USD vay của Quỹ, chị làm công việc thu mua phế liệu. Không giống như suy nghĩ của nhiều người, thu mua phế liệu là một công việc chỉ mang lại nguồn thu nhập đủ dùng cho nhu cầu hàng ngày và khó phát triển mở rộng, việc sắp xếp tổ chức hợp lý cộng với ý chí quyết tâm đã đưa chị Bảy từ một người đi thu mua phế liệu thành chủ cửa hàng trên địa bàn xã Tiên Dược. Từ thu mua một số lượng nhỏ để rồi đi bán lại cho các đại lý thu mua 10 năm trước, số lượng hàng thu mua ngày càng tăng dần theo thời gian. Chúng được sắp xếp phân loại sau đó chị Bảy chủ động tìm nguồn tiêu thụ cho từng thứ. 3 con của chị đã trưởng thành và đều tham gia vào công việc thu mua, giao hàng. Chị Bảy đang đăng ký xin vay 1200 USD để tăng số lượng hàng thu mua nhằm mở rộng quy mô kinh doanh.

loans.use: collect and sell wasted materials to factories reprocess

loans.name: Muhabbat

texts.ru:
A. Muhabbat has been selling women’s clothes for six years. She is married, has secondary education. Her husband works as a painter, he renovates apartments. She started getting loans from Microinvest in 2002. Then her assets were 200$. She started from selling cosmetics then moved to women’s clothes. Her assets have increased to 1200$. Her mother helps her with the business. She travels once a month to purchase goods. In the future she wants to increase inventory and travel to purchase goods more often. P.S. The picture is of her mother

Translated from Russian by Asya Lisak, Kiva Volunteer.

Абдуллоева Мухаббат занимается продажей женской одежды уже шесть лет. Замужем, образование среднее. Муж работает маляром, он ремонтирует квартиры. С 2002 года начала кредитоваться в «Микроинвест»-е. Тогда её активы состовляли около 200$. Она занималась торговлей парфюмерий, затем перешла на продажу женской одежды. Сейчас ее активы возросли до 1200$. В её деятельности помогает её мать. За товаром ездит раз в месяц. В дальнейшем хочет увеличить товарооборот и ездить за товаром чаще. P.S. На фото её мать.

loans.use: increase assortment

loans.name: Akif

texts.en:
Akif is an IDP originally from Khojali, an occupied district of Azerbaijan. In 1993, he fled Khojali to start a new life in Baku. He is a husband and a father of one child.

In 1998, he started his auto repair business. However, after several years, his business began to face a lot of tough competition from other businesses in the same industry. Thus, he applied and has received an initial loan from the Normicro Baku branch. He has invested this money in varying the number of paint colors for his shop.

Akif hopes to receive another loan amount of $1,100 so that he can further purchase equipment and other raw materials for his auto business.

loans.use: To buy equipment and raw materials for his business

loans.name: Mahbuba

texts.ru:
Y. Mahbuba is married, has 3 children. She has a secondary education. Husband works in the town phone company as a technician. Children go to school and help their mother with her business after school. She sells food. Previously she sold traditional flat-breads; her assets then were around 250$. Gradually after phased financing she extended the business and started selling food. Her assets have increased to 700$. She also provides telephony service. In the future she wants to increase inventory and improve the location of the business.

Translated from Russian by Asya Lisak, Kiva Volunteer.

Юнусова Махбуба замужем, имеет 3х детей. Образование среднее. Муж работает в городском телефоном сети - монтером. Дети учатся в школе и после школы они помогают в торговле своей матери. Она продает продукты питания. Раньше продавала лепешки, тогда её активы были около 250$. Постепенно после шагового кредитования займа она расширилась и начала продавать продукты питания. Сейчас её активы достигли до 700$. Также она предоставляет услуги телефонной связи. В дальнейшем хочет расширить товарооборот и улучшить место своей деятельности.

loans.use: increase assortment

loans.name: Fizza

texts.en:
Fizza is a 44 year-old, married woman with two children. She and her husband (as seen in the picture) started their own business in 1998. In 2005, Fizza received her first loan from Normicro Baku branch. In time, their business received a second loan.

Fizza invested these two loan amounts she received from Normicro to complete the building of her shop and to buy electronic control instruments. She hopes to further grow their business by purchasing new electronic equipment to aid in additional repair services. Fizza is requesting a loan amount of $1,000 to accomplish this.

loans.use: To purchase new equipment for shop

loans.name: Komilkhodjha

texts.ru:
S. Komilkhodjha is 29 years old; he sells food. He has a family, 3 children. Children go to school and kindergarten. He has been in business for 13 years. He started his business from 150$. Now his assets have increased to 1100$. During financing he bought refrigerator showcase. He gets his inventory from local suppliers. In the future he wants to open one more retail spot and expand the range of goods.

Translated from Russian by Asya Lisak, Kiva Volunteer.

Солиходжаев Комилходжа – 29 лет, занимается продажей продуктами питания. Семейный, имеет троих детей. Дети учатся в школе и ходят в детский сад. Вот уже 13 лет занимается торговлей. Начал свою деятельность с 150$. Сейчас его активы возросли до 1100$. В период кредитования приобрел холодильник-витрину. Товар берет у местных поставщиков. В дальнейшем хочет открыть еще одну торговую точку и расширить ассортимент продукта.

loans.use: increase assort ment and activity place

loans.name: Zainab

texts.ru:
T. Zainab is in retail. She is a widow, has three children. In her hard life this business is the main source of income because her children are grown up and busy taking care of their own families. She sells everyday food. She began getting loans from “Microinvest” in 2004; at that time her assets were 100$. Thanks to successful business and targeted use of loan after a certain time she bought cocktail-maker and refrigerator. Now her assets grew to 500$. She is planning to expand the range of goods and buy a permanent retail spot.

Translated from Russian by Asya Lisak, Kiva Volunteer.

Турсунова Зайнаб – занимается торговлей. Вдова, имеет троих детей. В её нелегкой жизни это деятельность является основным источником дохода, так как дети взрослые, и каждый занят заботой о своей семье. Она продает продукты ежедневного питания. Начала кредитоваться с 2004года в «Mикроинвест»-е, тогда ее активы составляли 100$. Благодаря успешному бизнесу и целевому использованию займа она через определенное время кредитования приобрела коктейльницу и холодильник. Сейчас её активы возросли до 500$. В дальнейшем планирует увеличить ассортимент и приобрести постоянную торговую точку.

loans.use: increase assortment and activity plase

loans.name: Elshan

texts.en:
Elshan is a married man with three children. He lives and runs his business in the town of Lokbatan.

His business came into existence in 1999. Just this year, he received a $1,000 loan from the Normicro Baku branch. With this money, he was able to purchase two ice cream refrigerators so that he could sell dairy products. Now, Elshan hopes to receive an additional loan amount of $1,100 from Normicro so that he can further increase the assortment of his food products. This will provide more choice and variety to his customers.

loans.use: To increase variety of food products

loans.name: Mahfirat

texts.ru:
Y. Mahfirat is 22 years old, not married. She has secondary education. She sells fruits and vegetables. She started her business in 2004. She had 130$ in assets. After receiving loan they grew to 500$. She also works as a seamstress in a workshop. Her mother helps with the business - she substitutes her during the work day. She gets her inventory from local suppliers. In the future she wants to expand her business and add groceries to her inventory. P.S – The picture is of her mother

Translated from Russian by Asya Lisak, Kiva Volunteer.

Юнусова Махфират- 22 лет, не замужем. Образование среднее. Занимается торговлей фруктами и овощами. Начала свою деятельность в 2004 году. Тогда её активы были на 130$. После получения займа они возросли до 500$. Она также работает швеёй в швейном цехе. В деятельности помогает её мать, во время рабочего дня она заменяет её. Товар берет у местных поставщиков. В дальнейшем хочет расширить и добавить в свой ассортимент продукты питания. P.S- На фото ее мать.

loans.use: increase assortment and add food trade

loans.name: Mammad

texts.en:
Mammad is a 33 year-old, married man and father of one child who lives with his family in the town of Lokbatan. While unemployed, he began to think through potential business start-up ideas.

During this time, he decided to start his first private business. In 2006, he received a $500 loan from the Normicro Baku branch and invested it into his tailoring business. His business is now up and running, but many improvements can still be made to it in order to ensure its sustainability. Now, he is requesting $1,000 so that he can purchase additional raw materials to provide better tailoring services to his growing customers.

loans.use: To buy raw materials

loans.name: Concepción

texts.es:
Mrs. Concepción P. R. is 55 years old, she is a widow a has a 27 year old daughter and 2 sons, one is 24 and the other 13 years old. She shares her home with her younger son and her oldest son’s family. She has her own grocery store at home since 5 years ago, her grocery store’s name is “Lucy” because of her oldest daughter who is now working in Madrid, Spain, because she couldn’t find work in Paraguay. In the store, Concepción sells general products like rice and mandioca, also sells meat, and herbs for the preparation of mate and tereté (two traditional and popular beverages similar to tea), candies, gas, books. Her clients are her neighbors and other people who live near by home. Concepción says the success of her business depends on the diversity of her products, so she acquired her first loan with Fundación Paraguaya two years ago to increase inventory. Concepción goes once a week to the central marker and she also buys from a vehicle that sells products to her home, but they charge for the delivery service. So she is asking a $300 loan that would allow her to buy at wholesale prices and sell in larger quantities and expand her business. Also her daughter will help her build a little house just for the grocery store, because currently the store is place on her living room, this will allow her sell more products and keep on helping her family.

Translated from Spanish by N.D., Kiva Volunteer.

La Señora Concepción P. R., de 55 años de edad, es viuda con una hija de 27 años y dos hijos, uno de 24 y otro de 13 años. Comparte su casa con su hijo menor y la familia de su hijo mayor. Desde hace cinco años tiene su propia despensa en su casa, a la cual le puso el nombre de “Lucy” por su hija mayor que actualmente se encuentra trabajando en Madrid, España, ya que no pudo encontrar empleo en Paraguay. En la despensa, Concepción vende artículos de primera necesidad como arroz y mandioca, además vende productos como carne, yerba para la preparación de mate y tereré (dos bebidas tradicionales muy populares), caramelos, gas y artículos de librería. Sus clientes son sus vecinos y otras personas que viven cerca de su casa. Concepción comenta que el éxito de su negocio depende de que haya surtido, por lo tanto sacó su primer crédito la Fundación Paraguaya hace dos años para surtir su negocio. Concepción va una vez por semana al mercado central de abasto y el resto del tiempo compra de un carro que le lleva los productos hasta la casa, sin embargo cobran por este servicio. Por lo tanto, está pidiendo un crédito de $300 que le permitirá comprar por mayor ya que de este modo le salen más económicos los productos y este le permite venderlos en mayores cantidades y así expandir su negocio. También dice que su hija le va a ayudar a construir una casita dedicada a la despensa, ya que por el momento la despensa está instalada en donde debería ser la sala esto le permitirá vender productos con más variedad y así seguir proviniendo para sus dependientes.

loans.use: Buy meat, milk, tomatoes, potatoes, carrots, sugar, salt.

loans.name: Alicia

texts.es:
Mrs. Alicia Alonso D. L., is 48 years old, she is married with Mr. Higinio L. Santander and they have 4 kids, two sons and two daughters. Her two sons work (one of them in São Paulo, Brasil), one of her daughters is a housewife and the other one is near to finish high school. Her husband works in construction, but the work is scatter and currently he has no job. So, Alicia works sawing lingerie for ladies, bikinis, pajamas, etc. and with her work, she has been able to raise her family. Alicia never got the chance to study because her mom maD. her work since she was 9 years old to help her family. But her uncle helped her pay for her studies in secret since she was 14 years old and that is how she learn her profession, until her mom noticed and took her off school. When she got married with her husband’s help, she went during 3 years to a school for adults and there she learned sawing too. Then she went to work to her niece’s atelier. Unfortunately, things were not going well, and one of her sons was near loosing his school year, so she decided to work as a maid at a near by house, while she was also sawing. Alicia got her first credit with Fundación Paraguaya 5 years ago to buy materials like fabric, threads and laces. Right now she sells her clothes to stores in the city, but her dream is to be able one day to sell clothes of her own signature. She needs a loan of $400 to by materials and be able to keep rising her family, and looking for a better future for her children. She says “all I do, I do it for them.”

Translated from Spanish by N.D., Kiva Volunteer.

La Señora Alicia Alonso D. L., D. 48 años, es casada con el Señor Higinio L. Santander y tienen cuatro hijos dos mujeres y dos varones. Sus dos hijos trabajan (uno D. ellos en São Paulo, Brasil), una D. sus hijas es ama D. casa y la otra está por terminar el colegio. Su esposo es constructor, sin embargo trabaja D. manera irregular y actualmente se encuentra sin empleo por falta D. trabajo. Por lo tanto, Alicia se dedica a fabricar ropa interior para damas, bikinis, piyamas, etc., así ha podido criar a su familia. Alicia nunca tuvo la oportunidad D. estudiar porque su mamá le hizo trabajar a los nueve años para apoyar al resto D. la familia. Sin embargo, a los 14 años su tío le pagaba los estudios en secreto y así aprendí lo básico D. su profesión, hasta que su mamá se dio cuenta y la sacó D. la escuela. Cuando ya se casó y contaba con el apoyo D. su esposo, asistió durante tres años a una escuela para adultos y allí aprendió bien la costura. Luego se fue a trabajar en el taller D. su sobrina. Desafortunadamente, las cosas iban mal, y uno D. sus hijos estaba por perder el año, entonces decidió trabajar como empleada doméstica en una casa cercana, a la par que hacia sus costuras. Alicia sacó su primer crédito D. la Fundación Paraguaya hace cinco años para comprar materiales como goma, hilo, tela y encaje. Ahora mismo venD. su ropa tienda D. ropas D. la ciudad, pero su sueño es D. un día poder vender bajo su propia marca. Hoy desea solicitar un crédito D. $400 para comprar más materiales y así poder seguir criando a su familia, buscando un futuro mejor para sus hijos. Dice ella, “todo lo que hago yo hago por ellos.”

loans.use: Buy fabric, laces, threads at wholesale

loans.name: Darío

texts.es:
Mr. Darío R., is 45 years old, he lives with his partner Ramona Domínguez and they have a 12 year old daughter who is currently on 7th grade. He used to work as a cook but left that job 8 years ago because he had to work at night and it was very dangerous, so he opened his own grocery store at home, which he manages with her wife. They sell general products like rice, mandioca, meat, herbs to prepare mate and tereré (two popular and traditional beverages), bear, chicken and eggs, also fast good like empanadas and Paraguayan soup (which is like a corn patty a typical Paraguayan meal). Darío is not only a successful entrepreneur, he is also socially responsible, currently he serves as vice-president of a commission that with City Hall help money from the World Bank, is working to improve life conditions of the community, to give them security to the children that work as garbage recyclers, who he sees as the future (Darío says there are more school age kids in his community than in any other in Paraguay). Mr. Darío R. has very good perspectives with his store, because right now the city has begun building a manufacture to process recycling plastics from the garbage disposal next to his home, which will increase the number of clients because the workers are already having breakfast and lunch at his store. So he wants to buy a motorcycle to bring more merchandise so he doesn’t have to pay anyone else for delivery, that is why he is requesting a $400 loan to buy the motorcycle.

Translated from Spanish by N.D., Kiva Volunteer.

El Señor Darío R., de 45 años, está viviendo en pareja con Ramona Domínguez tienen una hija de 12 años que actualmente está estudiando en el séptimo grado. Anteriormente trabajaba como cocinero pero dejó este cargo hace ocho años porque tenía que trabajar de noche y era peligroso, por lo tanto abrió su propia despensa en su casa, la cual cuida con su mujer. Venden productos de primera necesidad como arroz y mandioca, carne, yerba para la preparación de mate y tereré (dos bebidas tradicionales muy populares), cerveza, pollos y huevos caseros, además comidas rápidas como empanadas y sopa paraguaya (una especie de torta de maíz, una comida típica del Paraguay). Darío no solo es un emprendedor exitoso, también emprendedor socialmente responsable, actualmente sirve como vicepresidente de una comisión que, con el apoyo del Municipio de la ciudad y fondos provenientes, entre otros, del Banco Mundial, está trabajando para mejorar las condiciones en la comunidad para brindarles seguridad a los niños pobre que trabajan en el vertedero como recicladores, los cuales ve como el futuro (comenta que en su comunidad hay más niños en edad escolar que en cualquier otra comunidad en Paraguay). Darío tiene muy buenas perspectivas con su despensa, pues ahora mismo han empezado a construir una fábrica para procesar plásticos reciclados en el vertedero a lado de su casa, el cual significa un aumento en el número de clientes: los obreros ya están desayunando y almorzando en su despensa. Por lo tanto, quiere comprarse una motocicleta para traer mercadería sin tener que pagarle a otra persona por el servicio, y con este motivo está pidiendo un préstamo de $400 para adquirir la motocicleta.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Business Description

Our friend Maria is dedicated to the sales of clothing, such as pants, t-shirts, blouses, dresses... etc. In addition to having 3 years experience working independently, she is also a teacher at a school in her community. In spite of the fact that her husband passed away she has faced the hardships of generating income for her family, taking care of her only child, and attending to her business from very early in the morning every day of the week.

Use of the Loan

Maria needs the loan in order to be able to buy more merchandise and offer a greater variety of products to her clients. In this way she will be able to gain new clients as a result of the hard work that she puts into her business day after day. Maria needs this loan in order to cover various costs of her business and in order to keep her clients satisfied.

Personal Information

Maria is 41 years old and lives alone with her 17 year old daughter, who, thanks to Maria's hard work and efforts, is able to continue studying. She also helps with the activities of the house which has a cement structure. Maria's dream is for her business to grow so she can increase her income and come out ahead. Maria is confident that as she continues to adapt her home on her own land, she will eventually be able to earn additional income by renting out her home.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Kirkvold, Kiva volunteer.

Descripción del Negocio

Nuestra amiga Maria se dedica a la venta de ropa, como pantalones, camisetas, blusas, vestidos…etc. Teniendo como experiencia 3 anos, trabajando independientemente, también es maestra de una escuela de su comunidad. A pesar de que su esposo falleció desde este tiempo tuvo la necesidad de generar ingresos para su familia, teniendo a cargo un solo hijo, atendiendo desde muy temprano en la mañana todos los días de la semana

Uso del Préstamo

Maria necesita el préstamo para comprar mas mercadería y ofrecerles a su clientela variedades de productos, de tal manera que su numero de clientes aumente, como resultado del esfuerzo realizado tras el día a día de trabajo, Maria esta en la necesidad de adquirir el préstamo para cubrir sus necesidades y la de su clientela y así mantenerlos satisfechos.

Información Personal

Maria tiene 41 anos de edad, en donde vive solamente con su hija de 17 anos de edad, en la que gracias al esfuerzo realizado por parte de Maria la mantiene estudiando. Donde también le ayuda con las actividades de la casa que es de estructura de cemento. Los sueños de Maria es incrementar su negocio de tal manera que crezca en su actividad e incrementar sus ingresos y así salir adelante. Maria tiene la confianza de seguir adecuando casa en terreno propio y poder de esta forma obtener otros ingresos por medio de arriendo de vivienda.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise

loans.name: Edith

texts.es:
Description of Business

Edith started her business 3 years ago. The products that she sells are: provisions of primary necessity, gifts, and toys. She attends to her clientele in a personal way, every day from 6am until 9pm. Her business is located in her home.

Use of the Loan

Edith needs this loan in order to invest in the acquisition of more supplies and new jewelry products. In this way she will offer a greater variety of products to her clients. She will take advantage of the opportunity to expand her business by offering more and improving the quality of her services.

Personal Information

Edith is 34 years old. She has 3 children that are studying. Her husband works as a laboror. Edith takes care of her brother-in-law that is suffering from advanced diabetes. Her business was started with the capital that she managed to obtain with the small amount of savings that are the fruits of her husbands labor. Her business will take up a part of their home. She aspires to improve and grow with her business. In this way she will be able to collaborate in a better way and cover the expenses of her home.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Kirkvold, Kiva volunteer.

Descripción del Negocio

Edith inicio su negocio hace 3 años. Los productos que vende son: Víveres de primera necesidad, regalos, Juguetes. La atención de su clientela la realiza de manera personal todos los días desde las 6am-a -9pm. Su negocio esta ubicado en su domicilio.

Uso del Préstamo

Edith necesita del préstamo para invertir en la adquisición de más víveres y nuevos productos de bisutería. De esta manera ofrecer nueva variedad de productos a sus clientes. Aprovechando la oportunidad de expandir su negocio ofreciendo y mejorando la calidad de sus servicios

Información Personal

Edith tiene 34 años. Tiene 3 hijos que están estudiando. Su esposo trabaja como obrero. Edith aloja en su hogar aun cuñado que padece la enfermedad de la diabetes avanzada .El negocio lo inicio con un poco de capital que logro obtener en base a los pequeños ahorros fruto del trabajo de su esposo. Para su negocio ocupa parte de su vivienda. Aspira ha mejorar y crecer junto con su negocio. Para de esta manera colaborar de mejor manera y cubrir los gastos de su casa.

loans.use: Purchase of new jewelry products and supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase more plantains

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in necessary baking ingredients, such as flour and sugar

loans.name: Juana Antonia

texts.en:
Juana Antonia has been selling beautiful woven fabrics on the street for about six months. She weaves some of the smaller items herself and buys the larger items for resale. She goes on the bus every day to the nearby city of Quetzaltenango and spends all day selling. Juana's husband left her about ten years ago with three children. She has succeeded in getting at least some schooling for all, but the eldest (now 17) had to drop out after sixth grade because they just couldn't afford the school expenses. The other two, 12 and 14, are still continuing on in school.
Juana can make a profit of about US$3.30 each day with her full day's effort, but she battles on, because it's the way to fulfill her dream of a successful education and life for the children. As with most salespeople, Juana will invest this loan in inventory.
Written Kiva Fellows:  Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay

loans.use: Purchase more yarn for weaving and more fabric for sale

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is 32 years old, and the mother of 3. Her husband works in a paint factory and helps her with the business in whatever way he can. Her store has allowed her to make significant improvements to her home, which only a couple of years ago, was still made out of wood.

Irene has a general store where she sells clothes, school supplies, decorations and snacks. She has had this business for about 6 years. Prior to this she was a door to door clothing saleswoman. She set up her business with the intention of continuing her clothes sales, but she found that other items were also profitable and sold faster. She buys most of her products in bulk. This allows her to also travel to rural towns and sell in large quantities to micro businesses there. She is seeking her second loan in order to continue investing in wholesale quantities in order to increase her profits.

loans.use: Invest in more merchandise

loans.name: Juana Luisa

texts.en:
Juana Luisa P. B., 30, learned to sew on a manual sewing machine ten years ago, and managed to buy a treadle machine with help from her father. However, in recent years, she hasn't been able to afford material to make clothes with, so the machine was mouldering in the corner. With this loan through Friendship Bridge, Juana will buy materials to make the delicate blouses with hand embroidery that are beloved by local women. Material for each blouse costs about US$20 and she can sell the blouse for about US$26, for a $6 profit. Juana completed school to  the sixth grade level, and can read and write both Spanish and her mother tongue, Quiché. She wants to make sure that all her three children stay in school, but she also wants to make sure and teach them how to sew so they can join in the family business.  Her husband is also a weaver and they want to pass on that ancient tradition to the children as well, teaching them how to produce the beautiful local fabric which can be sewed into skirts, table covers, bed clothing, and shawls.
Written by Kiva Fellows: Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay

loans.use: Fabric for making blouses

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia R., 26, grows vegetables in the rich soil in the highlands of Guatemala. In her rented plot of land she grows lettuce and onions. She is able to grow two crops in one year on the two plots or cuerdas she rents, totaling about 80’x80’ (28x28 meters). With this loan she will buy seed, fertilizer and pesticides. 
Her goal for the future is to to expand into cattle because the market is favorable for cattle right now. Alicia is married, has 3 children and owns her home. Though she never went to school and cannot read or write she knows education is important and works hard to send her children to school. The youngest one is 4 years old and will be ready to enter school next year.Alicia's village is nestled right against the side of the Santa Maria volcano, part of a complex of volcanoes that regularly rumbles  and that completely destroyed the village in the early 20th century. It's a place of beautiful green hillsides and lush plots of corn and vegetables, all divided into little sections called cuerdas. The poorer women often rent just one cuerda and try to grow their own corn for the family and sell some vegetables from it. Those who have more sometimes own two or more cuerdas, and sometimes rent even more. It's hard work, and they always refer to their life as a "battle" or "struggle", but they continue with the battle to feed their families and keep the kids in school.
Written by Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay, Kiva Fellows

loans.use: Seed, fertilizer, and pesticides for her vegetable garden

loans.name: Juana

texts.en:
Juana S. G., 38, has a little juice and chicken business. She wants to buy 12 more chicks, half for meat and half for egg production. She also wants to make and sell fresh orange juice, so will buy the hand juicer and a table so she can sell in the nearby town. Juana is separated from her husband and has two small children. She only had two years of schooling, so her big dream is to provide school for the children so they can have a bigger head start in life.  Juana is a member of the women's group "Nuevo Amanecer". 
Written by Kiva Fellows: Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay

loans.use: Orange juicer and 12 Chicks, half for meat and half for eggs

loans.name: Cornelia

texts.en:
Cornelia C. X., 52, can be found just outside the entrance of the school every  day selling fruits in bag, juices, empanadas and crackers to the school kids.. At the beginning of every day, she puts aside the coin from her first sale of the day to give to the church. She believes it brings her good luck to think of others in need. She also owns 4 little plots of lands and rents 10 more plots of land where she grows vegetables. A plot of land is known in this part of Guatemala as a cuerda and is about one sixth of a football field. She sells the vegetables she grows  in the large market in Quetzaltenango. Cornelia is an ambitious woman. With the next loan she hopes to buy 100 chicks and 3 bulls. She and her husband work hard because they want to be able to leave some land for a house to all of their 5 grown children. Unlike most women of her age in this community, Cornelia actually went to school and finished the third grade, so she can read and write. All of her children also spent at least a few years in school. Cornelia's village is nestled right against the side of the Santa Maria volcano, part of a complex of volcanoes that regularly rumbles tand that completely destroyed the village in the early 20th century. It's a place of beautiful green hillsides and lush plots of corn and vegetables, all divided into little sections called cuerdas. The poorer women often rent just one cuerda and try to grow their own corn for the family and sell some vegetables from it. Those who have more sometimes own two or more cuerdas, and sometimes rent even more. It's hard work, and they always refer to their life as a "battle" or "struggle", but they continue with the battle to feed their families and keep the kids in school.
Written by Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay, Kiva Fellows

loans.use: 100 chicks and 3 calves

loans.name: Gabriela

texts.en:
Gabriela E. C. is 27 and only finished third grade, but you wouldn't know it by her bearing and her business. She runs a well-furnished little school- and office-supplies store where her husband also does building design and drafting.  She started the business originally because there just wasn't an appropriate store in the town to provide things like notebooks, pencils, glue, and other school supplies.
This loan will go toward purchase of merchandise for the store. Gabriela has big dreams for her life, including providing houses for her children when they become adults. Gabriela has three children, and as you'd expect, the older ones are starting school.
Written by Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay, Kiva Fellows

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for sale

loans.name: Jaime

texts.en:
Jaime has about 8 years of experience running and owning food markets. Prior to this, he used to be a street vendor, but he decided to switch due to the instability of the work. He started off by selling vegetables, but now he has diversified his product line to include many different foods and home supplies.

Jaime is 27 years old and has one son who is 6 years old. When he received his first loan with Mifex his wife was expecting a new child in only 2 months, putting pressure on Jaime to generate income for his growing family. Jaime was extremely happy to receive his first loan and was able to invest in his business before the arrival of his child. The investments he made certainly made it easier for Jaime to handle the costs associated with a new baby. The loan meant a lot for him and his wife. Both feel they were able to provide the very best they could for their new baby. His business continued to do well as he invested in a new glass case. He hopes a second loan will allow him to buy more glass display cases and also more merchandise.

loans.use: Buy merchandise and improve his store presence

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Like most of the women in her village, Magdalena has many irons in the fire. She has two little plots of land where she grows corn, the staple food of Guatemala. She also grows vegetables, and with this loan she will buy a calf to raise for sale. 
Magdalena is 40 and has five children, four of school age. Two of them are still in school, but the 13- and 14-year-olds are now working instead of going to school. She herself never went to school and does not read or write. Magdalena's husband left long ago. Magdalena hopes someday to rent another little plot of land to grow more vegetables. Magdalena's village is nestled right against the side of the Santa Maria volcano, part of a complex of volcanoes that regularly rumbles the area and that completely destroyed the village in the early 20th century. It's a place of beautiful green hillsides and lush plots of corn and vegetables, all divided into little sections called cuerdas. The poorer women often rent just one cuerda and try to grow their own corn for the family and sell some vegetables from it. Those who have more sometimes own two or more cuerdas, and sometimes rent even more. It's hard work, and they always refer to their life as a "battle" or "struggle", but they continue with the battle to feed their families and keep the kids in school.
Written by Randy Fay and Nancy Lewis, Kiva Fellows

loans.use: Purchase a calf to raise for sale

loans.name: Maria Florinda

texts.en:
Maria Florinda C. is 29 and earns most of her living by buying and selling vegetables in the market. She'll buy at one market and then sell at another, making perhaps US$7 to $13 per day and taking home half of that after travel  expenses and food and the like. With this loan Maria is branching out and buying a calf, hoping that the sale of the calf later will increase her income. She'll buy the calf for about US$200 and hope to sell it later for between US$300 and $400. Maria has three school-aged children, and all are in school. She herself had no schooling at all and cannot read or write. She dreams someday of buying the plot of land  by their house, which would cost about US$7000. Maria's village is nestled right against the side of the Santa Maria volcano, part of a complex of volcanoes that regularly rumbles the area and that completely destroyed the village in the early 20th century. It's a place of beautiful green hillsides and lush plots of corn and vegetables, all divided into little sections called cuerdas. The poorer women often rent just one cuerda and try to grow their own corn for the family and sell some vegetables from it. Those who have more sometimes own two or more cuerdas, and sometimes rent even more. It's hard work, and they always refer to their life as a "battle" or "struggle", but they continue with the battle to feed their families and keep the kids in school.
Writtten by Randy Fay and Nancy Lewis, Kiva Fellows

loans.use: Purchase and raise a calf for sale

loans.name: Manuela Climaca

texts.es:
Maria Francisca, 51, and her mother Manuela Climaca, 73, have a pretty difficult life. They have no family except each other, but Maria has to live and earn a living for the both of them three hours away in La Mesilla, near the Mexican border.

Maria sells dishes in the street in La Mesilla, at three for US$1.35. On a normal day she can earn a profit of about US$3.30. She can come home to care for her mother only occasionally. Maria Francisca will use this loan to purchase more inventory, hopefully at a better price, allowing for slightly improved profits.

Written by Kiva Fellows: Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay

loans.use: Purchase more inventory of dishes and other kitchen items

loans.name: Maria Mercedes

texts.en:
Maria Mercedes M. Garcia, 50, buys vegetables at one market and then sells them at another market in the major city of Quetzaltengo. Some of the vegetables she sells are radishes, carrots, lettuce, and other cool weather vegetables. 
Maria  will buy a calf with the next loan and raise it to sell. She does not have her own pasture so she will have to take the bull to various grazing places, like along the side of the road. The town where she lives grows lots of vegetables and there is little if any land for cattle to graze, so she will lead it by a rope to various places where there is a patch of grass to graze. It might be a mound of grass in the back of the neighbor's house or along the side of the road or high in the hills. She may tie it up there or may hang out with it all day so the it can eat enough to grow into a full blown bull to sell for the meat: She hopes to sell the bull for up to Q4000 ($525) Maria is a widow and lives with her daughter. She had five children and three lived to adulthood, but two died of a fever that struck the village. She has never had schooling and can not read.
As you can see in the picture, Maria wears the beautiful traditional Mayan skirt and top called a huipil which identifies what village she comes from. The huipil is the most valuable possession a woman from the highlands of Guatemala can own and is often their only possession. She is very proud of the three beautiful huipils she has been able to acquire over her adult life.
Written by Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay, Kiva Fellows

loans.use: Purchase and raise a calf for sale

loans.name: Maria Teresa

texts.en:
Maria Teresa T., 29, raises broccoli, cauliflower, and a little bean called "aba" and sells them in the major market in the nearby city of Quetzaltenango. She has only one little plot of land to raise her vegetables, and it's rented and costs about US$27/month. With her little business in the market she can make perhaps US$10/day. Maria will use this loan for seed, fertilizer, and pesticides for her crop. She has four children, all of school age, and all in school. She's married, and her husband works in the fields for others. She didn't go to school, but she reads a little and can sign her own name on documents, instead of using the very common technique of signing with a thumb print.  Maria's village is nestled right against the side of the Santa Maria volcano, part of a complex of volcanoes that regularly rumbles the area and that completely destroyed the village in the early 20th century. It's a place of beautiful green hillsides and lush plots of corn and vegetables, all divided into little sections called cuerdas. The poorer women often rent just one cuerda and try to grow their own corn for the family and sell some vegetables from it. Those who have more sometimes own two or more cuerdas, and sometimes rent even more. It's hard work, and they always refer to their life as a "battle" or "struggle", but they continue with the battle to feed their families and keep the kids in school.
Written by Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay, Kiva Fellows

loans.use: Seed, fertilizer, and pesticides for vegetable crops

loans.name: Manuela

texts.en:
Manuela F. is 18 with no spouse or children and has started her business life off as a weaver of cloth for the local women. With this loan she'll pay off her own loom (about US$130) and will no longer have to borrow or rent a loom. The hand-crafted fabric she weaves is mostly used for the women's typical costumes. She sells it to others who make the fabric into clothing.Manuela's dream is to buy another loom, or maybe more than one, and to have employees weaving with her. She thinks she might accomplish this in a year or so. She also wants to learn how to do some of the delicate add-on weaving and embroidery that the local clothing requires, so she doesn't have to send out for that.
Written by Kiva Fellows: Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay

loans.use: Purchase more yarn for weaving  and pay off her own loom

loans.name: Micaela Julia

texts.en:
Micaela Julia X. has many irons in the fire. When the planting and harvesting seasons are in full swing, she spends almost all her time in her little plot of land, tending her corn and vegetables. But with this loan she will add chickens, turkeys, and a calf to the mix. And during the lulls in the agricultural seasons she also runs a tiny comedor, or eatery, where she serves simple lunches and coffee, hot chocolate, and soft drinks. Micaela is 46 and has seven children, five of whom are currently in school. She herself studied for six years when she was young, and loved it, but had to stop when she got married.  Her husband is currently working far away and hasn't been able to visit for two years, but is not getting enough work and expects to return this year. Micaela's village is nestled right against the side of the Santa Maria volcano, part of a complex of volcanoes that regularly rumbles the area and that completely destroyed the village in the early 20th century. It's a place of beautiful green hillsides and lush plots of corn and vegetables, all divided into little sections called cuerdas. The poorer women often rent just one cuerda and try to grow their own corn for the family and sell some vegetables from it. Those who have more sometimes own two or more cuerdas, and sometimes rent even more. It's hard work, and they always refer to their life as a "battle" or "struggle", but they continue with the battle to feed their families and keep the kids in school.
Written by Randy Fay and Nancy Lewis, Kiva Fellows

loans.use: Purchase chicks, turkeys, and a calf

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy more ingredients to make different types of dishes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy glass display cases

loans.name: Manuela Victoria

texts.en:
Manuela Victoria runs a little cafeteria serving fried potatoes and cafe con leche (coffee with milk). She just got it going 8 months ago, and with this loan she'll have a stove to add more to her menu, including garnachas, enchiladas, pupusas (a tortilla with fried pork rind and cheese).  Garnachas are fried wedges of tortillas and topped with refried beans, cheese and chile sauce. Manuela is just 21 years old, but is married with three small children, and has big entrepreneurial ambitions. She's thinking that this year she might be able to open a little eatery in the nearby city of Quetzaltenango, and maybe more in the future. But with her current operation Manuela pays about US$13/day for food and supplies, and ends up making a profit of about US$6.00/day.  She pays rent of US$55 per month. Manuela is a member of the women's group "Nueva Esperanza" and is just beginning with Friendship Bridge.
Written by Kiva Fellows: Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay

loans.use: A stove to allow her to fix pupusas and garnachas (traditional Guatemalan food)

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia runs a small restaurant with her mother. She began her entrepreneurial ventures as a clothes saleswoman. She decided to open up a restaurant with her mother in downtown Guayaquil. Unfortunately, the rent was too expensive there and she had to move the business to her home. She makes most of her money from the lunches she delivers to companies and at construction sites.

Although Sonia planned to invest in tables and chairs with her previous loan, she chose instead to buy a bigger pot and other new kitchen utensils. Cooking now is much easier and the quality of food has improved. Sonia provides lunches for many more clients now and she uses the help of her mother to deliver the food to the sites. She also has a second source of income selling clothes which she is very experienced doing. She will use her second loan to buy new foods so she can make more dishes. She also hopes she can use the profits to invest in more clothing to sell.

She is a single mother with two children who are in school. Her and her children live with Sonia’s mother who has always lent them a helping hand. Her dream is to own a home of her own.

loans.use: Buy more ingredients for the dishes in her restuarant

loans.name: Antonia

texts.en:
Antonia R. D. P., 50, is married to her wonderful husband, Justo, and has four grown children. She has been selling medicine from the front of her house for fifteen years. Recently she has branched out into growing produce and raising pigs for the local market and is immensely proud of the little tomato hothouse she's put together and of her three pigs. This year she sowed onions, tomatoes, cauliflower, and all are looking good. With this loan she'll buy seeds, fencing, finish the roof on the hothouse, and increase the inventory of medicines in her store.

Before working with Friendship Bridge, Antonia's group used to obtain credit from a Guatemalan government agency, Banco Comunal del FIS, but due to political changes, it shut down in October last year, so the group went searching for other credit providers and found Friendship Bridge.

Antonia went to school for two years when she was young, and her children all graduated with full high school educations, but they are unable to find work in their fields due to the current economic situation. Her dream for the future is for a better life for her family.

Antonia is a member of Women's group: "D. la Cruz" in Paxixil, San Francisco El Alto, Totonicapán

Written by Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay, Kiva Fellows.

loans.use: Seed and fencing for garden and greenhouse, inventory for store

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.en:
Maria Luisa G. T. started her candle sales business three years ago with an investment of just 3 Guatemalan Quetzals, or about US$0.40. Back then she would buy just a candle or two at a time and sell them in front of the local Catholic church during the town festival in late September. Now she makes her own candles and buys wax in hundred-pound packages.

Maria Luisa is 42 with four children. She's married and lives with her husband, but he no longer supports her either morally or economically, so she had to branch out and find a way to support herself, her 4 children and her 84 year old blind mother.

Maria will buy 200 pounds of paraffin wax for about US$130, some wicks, and a lot of used veladora glasses. She'll sell the candles for US$0.50 for the small ones up to $1.30 for the big ones. Someday she hopes to actually open a store, but the locations she's checked out cost about US$100/month, which is a lot of profit you have to make. But she has dreams, and hopes to grow her business to the point where she can do it.

Written by Kiva Fellows: Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay

loans.use: Purchase paraffin, wicks, and glasses for religious candles called Veladoras

loans.name: Juana Pax

texts.en:
Juana Pax T. G. is 34, but her family already has a thriving business sewing jeans for the local market. They buy denim, cut it, and sew it into various children's sizes, then sell wholesale in the weekly market in nearby San Francisco El Alto. The jeans have a professional, polished look, with a good cut and a nice label.

Juana is married and has four children, all of whom are in school. The oldest, 13, works half days in the shop and can turn out 4 pairs of jeans himself. The whole shop hums with activity, and can produce 15 pairs per day, which increases to 25 with the purchase of an additional electric sewing machine to replace the old treadle-style machine that one of the workers had to use. They can sell the jeans for about US$3.30 each; material for each costs about US$.90, so they make a tidy profit of over $2.00 on each pair.

Someday Juana would like to have her own store in San Francisco El Alto and sell at retail, with the higher markup that would provide.

Women's group: "De la Cruz" in Paxixil, San Francisco El Alto, Totonicapán

Written by Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay, Kiva Fellows

loans.use: Purchase electric sewing machine

loans.name: Lidia

texts.en:
Lidia C. O., 40, is married and has no less than 13 children. Her husband works in the corn fields in this beautiful area of the highlands of Guatemala, but the family struggles to feed all the children. Lidia has just started a little neighborhood store and is in the first month of operation.

The roof of her 7x7 foot store is just old tiles resting on branches, and it leaks a lot in the six months of the rainy season (right now). With this loan she'll buy more juices, chips, soap and rice to sell in the store. As the business grows she'll improve the roof with sheeting to solve that problem.

Women's group: "De la Cruz" in Paxixil, San Francisco El Alto, Totonicapán

Written by Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay, Kiva Fellows

loans.use: Inventory purchase for store

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
In the photo you see Maria H. Gomez, who is 57 and married with seven grown children and nine grandchildren. Her farm is an hour's walk down into a deep valley below where she's standing – you can see the valley in the distance.

Maria has been in the chicken and egg business for ten years. Currently she has 60 hens that produce 60 eggs per day for a gross of about 40 Guatemalan Quetzals or US$5.30/day. And she's quite proud to have three milking cows as well. Maria will use half of this loan to build a henhouse, and the other half to buy more hens. She'd eventually like to buy three more cows as well.

Women's group: "De la Cruz" in Paxixil, San Francisco El Alto, Totonicapán

Written by Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay, Kiva Fellows

loans.use: Half for a hen house, half for more chickens

loans.name: Tomasa

texts.en:
Tomasa R. T., 24, has been sewing for ten years making sweatpants and jackets. She has expanded her business and now employs five other people. Her shop produces 144 items per week, and the jackets sell for as much as 60 Guatemalan Quetzals, or almost US$8.00. She sells the items at wholesale, by the dozen, in the market in nearby San Francisco El Alto. She'll use this loan to feed the shop's insatiable need for more fabric.

Tomasa's husband died about four years ago, leaving her with two small children. The older child is now in school, and the younger will start soon. Tomasa herself had two years of school as a child, so learned to read and write and speak Spanish in addition to her native Quiché.

Women's group: "De la Cruz" in Paxixil, San Francisco El Alto, Totonicapán

Written by Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay, Kiva Fellows

loans.use: Purchase fabric to sew sweatshirts and jackets

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Make physical improvements to his home and store

loans.name: Maria Roberta

texts.en:
Maria Roberta Gutiérrez T. is 51, married, and has two children. She's a weaver of traditional Mayan textiles, primarily belts. She can make twelve of these in a week, but her production is slow because of pain in her hands, and they often fall asleep due to the repetitive motion of weaving. Her week's work costs about US$16 in material, and she can sell it for about US$32, making a US$16 profit for the week.

With this little bit she supports her family. Her husband drinks too much and does not work, and of course this angers her. She ends up solely responsible for the family's support and wellbeing.

Maria is excited about how this loan will help her. With this capital she can buy more material to produce more belts.

Maria does have a small plot of land where she grows beans, corn, and apples, but it is not enough to feed the family. With the anticipated success of her business she hopes to be able to buy supplementary food for the family.

Maria's first and best language is the Mayan tongue Quiché. She has never gone to school and she doesn't read or write, but her children have gone, and they taught her to speak Spanish.

Written by Kiva Fellow: Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay

loans.use: Buy more yarn to make belts

loans.name: Petrona Celestina

texts.en:
Petrona Celestina S. G. has a small store and a small garden. She lives high above the highway along a path in an agricultural area, so her store is not in a densely populated area, but it serves a neighborhood need, selling snack foods, drinks, eggs, juices, and the like. She just started the store about 6 months ago, and is gradually growing the inventory, bit by bit. Petrona has 10 children, of whom five are still in school, so it's a struggle to keep up with school expenses.

Petrona will use this credit for a bit of carrot and radish seed so she can sell some of the produce from her garden, and to increase the inventory in her little store.

Petrona and her neighbors in the area speak mostly the Quiché language among themselves. Spanish is a second language that some speak well and others just a little.

Written by Kiva Fellows: Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay

loans.use: Radish and carrot seed for the garden, purchase more inventory for the store

loans.name: Berta

texts.en:
Berta Pelicó P. is a member of a group of women who all rent little plots of land to grow crops for a little bit of supplemental cash. Manuela rents her two little plots of land for about US$316/year, and grows onions and ornamental flower. She'll invest this loan in seed, fertilizer, and pesticides. Her little business brings in only about 15% of her income, so she also works extensively in the fields of others to make ends meet.

Berta's has simple goals: She'd like to someday get just a little cash saved up. And a far-reaching dream would be to buy a piece of her own land, which would cost the nearly unthinkable sum of US$1000 or more. Berta, 51, speaks mostly her native Quiché, but also speaks a good bit of Spanish, which she learned out of necessity in her work life. She didn't go to school as a girl and does not read or write. Cultivating crops is all she knows, but at least now she can work the fields at least a little bit for her own account, instead of working all the time for others.

Women's group: "De la Cruz" in La Estancia de la Cruz, Quetzaltenango

Written by Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay, Kiva Fellows

loans.use: Purchase seed, fertilizer, and pesticides for onion and flower crop

location.town: La Estancia de la Cruz, Quetzaltenango

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen X. G., 35, is a member of a group of women who all rent little plots of land to grow crops for a little bit of supplemental cash. Carmen rents her little plot of two cuerdas for about US$316/year, and grows lettuce, broccoli, and carrots. She'll invest this loan in seed, fertilizer, and pesticides. Her little business brings in only a small portion of her income, so she also works extensively in the fields of others to support herself and her 16-year-old.

Carmen is married with three children, 14, 15, and 18 years old, who are all in school. . Carmen herself never had any schooling, cannot read or write, and speaks only a smattering of Spanish, since day-to-day conversations are carried out in her native Quiché language. This of course isolates her a bit from economic opportunities in the mainstream economy of Guatemala, where business is carried out in Spanish.

Carmen dreams of somehow prospering in her business and building a house. Thankfully, the family's health has been good.

Women's group: "De la Cruz" in La Estancia de la Cruz, Quetzaltenango

Written by Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay, Kiva Fellows

loans.use: Purchase seed, fertilizer, and pesticides for lettuce, broccoli, and carrot crop

location.town: La Estancia de la Cruz, Quetzaltenango
